column6: Physical education foundations and activities adapted to the capabilities and needs of the handicapped student. Recommended by Kent Health Center.
Introduction to the principles of physical training. Practical application of these principles through a variety of activities.

The role of exercise in enhancing physical fitness. Lectures on principles of planning scientifically sound exercise programs. Laboratory experiences in personal fitness evaluation and exercise routines.
Application of sound training methods to achieve personal cardiovascular fitness through participation in a walking program.
(Repeatable for credit)
No or minimal swimming ability.
Five days of intensive skiing at commercial establishment with skill instruction and related lectures. Transportation, lodging, rental, lift fees are assessed.
(Repeatable for credit) Controlled registration.
(Repeatable for credit)

Presentation of the DVIDA bronze syllabus for Latin Dances. Introduction of Latin Rhythm dances, which will include the Merengue, Salsa, Rumba, Cha Cha and Samba. Includes proper technique, rhythm of the dance and approximately 10-15 figures for each dance.
Controlled registration.
(Repeatable for credit). Controlled registration.
Basic instruction in Volleyball skill and Wallyball game strategies.
Individuals beyond the lifesaving level are prepared to assume the responsibilities of lifeguards at pools or at non-surf open water beaches.
(Repeatable for credit). Controlled registration.
Application of sound training methods to achieve personal fitness through swimming.

A continuation of the basic techniques of racquetball, with an emphasis on refinement of skill performance, and an introduction to intermediate racquetball techniques and strategies that lead to higher levels of performance.
(Repeatable for credit). Controlled registration.
(Repeatable for credit). Controlled registration.
(Repeatable for credit). Controlled registration.

(Repeatable for intermediate and advanced levels) One hour riding, one hour lecture per week. Riding emphasis is placed upon acquisition of balance and proper form while maintaining control of the horse. Lecture provides knowledge and practice in care of horse.
To build on the basic hockey fundamentals, leading to advanced team play and game situations providing deeper insight into the game of hockey.
Must have taken PEB 11604 or have three months of experience in Karate.
Pilates is a form of fitness endeavors which unite the rhythmic performances and strength with the conditioning principles of the movement sciences.
(Repeatable for credit) Controlled registration.
Broomball is a recreational ice game played in an ice rink. Skills, tactics and plays are similar to those used in ice hockey.
(Repeatable for credit)
A basic course in the use of equipment in an average weight room and its application towards the development of strength and power.
The instruction in and practice of exercises based upon proper food selection for the purpose of weight control.
Fundamental skills and knowledge involved in the use of the nautilus for fitness development.
An aerobic program concerned with cardiovascular efficiency, flexibility and strength gain which is achieved through dance movement.
Basic through intermediate Nordic skiing technique, waxing, equipment and clothing selection, conditioning, winter safety considerations and trip planning. Student must supply equipment.

A continuation of the basic techniques of volleyball, with an emphasis on refinement of skill performance and an introduction to intermediate volleyball techniques and strategies that lead to higher levels of performance.

Trip planning and leadership, equipment and clothing selection, safety considerations, search and rescue, environmental ethics, map and compass, weekend backpacking trip. Student must supply equipment.

Basic paddling skills learned in a pool environment and then experienced in open lakes and white water situations. Canoe rental fee assessed. Students must be able to swim 100 yards and tread water for five minutes fully clothed.
(Repeatable for credit) Controlled registration.
(Repeatable for credit) Controlled registration.
Map and compass skills are learned to aid in wilderness survival. Easy to difficult courses are set in local parks and forest preserves.

Basic camping skills including: toolcraft, ropecraft, fire building, cooking, campsite management, equipment selection, safety considerations, environmental ethics, and map and compass for use on weekend trip. Students must supply own clothing and shelter.
Combination of lecture, activity classes and weekend field trip. Basic instruction in safe rope handling, knots, conditioning, climbing technique, belaying, anchor systems and rappelling.

Basic paddling skills learned in a pool environment and then experienced in open lakes and whitewater situations. Kayak rental fee assessed. Students must be able to swim 100 yards and tread water for five minutes fully clothed.

Introduction to skills and procedures needed to enjoy the sport of sailing. Boat design and construction, rigging, safety and a hands-on application stressed. Students must be able to swim 100 yards and tread water for five minutes fully clothed.

Adaptation of backpacking skills including trip planning, leadership, equipment, clothing, travel methods, orienteering, safety considerations, search and rescue, and survival skills in the winter environment. Student must supply equipment.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN EXERCISE, LEISURE AND SPORT
column6: Workshop in exercise, leisure and sport activities topics vary.
